title: Lebanese Bands Concert Is Canceled After Its Accused of Blasphemy
description: A Lebanese music festival has canceled a concert by a major indie music band, Mashrou Leila, after it was accused of blasphemy and received death threats because a member had shared an image of the singer Madonna as the Virgin Mary.

title: Ras G, 40, Hip-Hop Producer and Force in L.A. Music Scene, Dies
description: Ras G, an experimental hip-hop producer whose kaleidoscopic, throttling beats channeled a wide spectrum of black musical history and established him as a guiding light on the Los Angeles music scene, died on Monday at his home in the city. He was 40.

title: New York Galleries: What to See Right Now
description: Among the current crop of summer shows devoted to painting, Painters Reply: Experimental Painting in the 1970s and Now is a standout. Taking its name and conceit from a 1975 special issue of Artforum magazine, in which artists responded to a questionnaire about the state of the medium, the show, at Lisson Gallery, suggests the rich range of possibilities in which past and present experimental painting practices merge.

title: Nick Buoniconti, 78, Dies; All-Pro Linebacker Championed Medical Research
description: Nick Buoniconti, a tenacious middle linebacker who won two Super Bowls in the 1970s with the Miami Dolphins and in retirement turned his doggedness to finding a cure for his sons paralysis, died on Tuesday at his home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Colorectal Cancer Rises Among Younger Adults
description: Colorectal cancer is typically considered a disease of aging  most new cases are diagnosed in people over age 50. But even as the rates decrease in older adults, scientists have documented a worrisome trend in the opposite direction among patients in their 20s and 30s.

title: Why the Fed Cut Rates: To Try to Fix Last Years Mistake
description: Several of the questions directed at Jerome Powell at his Wednesday afternoon news conference boiled down to this: Why did you just cut interest rates when, by your own acknowledgment, the American economy looks perfectly solid? What good can this possibly achieve?

title: Trump Administration Imposes Sanctions on Irans Top Diplomat
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration took the unusual step on Wednesday of placing sanctions on Irans foreign minister, essentially cutting off the clearest avenue for talks with Iran by punishing the man who negotiated the 2015 nuclear agreement.

title: Hal Prince, Through the Archives of The Times
description: Hal Prince was a fixture on the pages of The New York Times for more than five decades. He earned his space there in the same way he earned 21 Tony Awards  by contributing his talents as a producer and director to some of the most important musical theater productions of the 20th century. Mr. Prince died on Wednesday at 91 in Reykjavik, Iceland.

title: Cisco to Pay $8.6 Million to Settle Government Claims of Flawed Tech
description: WASHINGTON  Cisco Systems agreed on Wednesday to pay $8.6 million to settle claims that it sold video surveillance technology that it knew had a significant security flaw to federal, state and local government agencies.

title: Trump Orders Navy to Strip Medals From Prosecutors in War Crimes Trial
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump intervened Tuesday once again on behalf of a Navy SEAL who was charged but acquitted of war crimes in the death of a captured Islamic State fighter in Iraq, ordering the military to punish the prosecutors who tried the case in the first place.

title: When Kamala Harris and Joe Biden Clashed on Busing and Segregation
description: Perhaps no moment from the first Democratic debates in June was more dramatic than the tense exchange between former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris of California. The two Democrats sparred on the issues of race, segregation and school busing.

title: Juul Says It Doesnt Target Kids. But Its E-Cigarettes Pull Them In.
description: Over 3.6 million middle and high school students used e-cigarettes last year, up by 1.5 million over 2017. The use of Juul, the most popular brand in the country, appears to have led this alarming increase among middle and high school students. This should not be a surprise.

title: Kim Jong-un Calls North Koreas New Rocket System an Inescapable Distress to Enemies
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said on Thursday that its leader, Kim Jong-un, attended the testing of a new type of large-caliber, multiple-launch, guided rocket system that could expand the Norths ability to strike South Korea and the American forces stationed there.

title: With Zack Greinke, the Astros Return to What Worked in 2017
description: Two summers ago, the Houston Astros traded for a right-handed pitcher born in 1983 who had once won the American League Cy Young Award. That pitcher, Justin Verlander, carried the Astros to the World Series, which they won for the first time.

title: The Republican Exodus From Congress
description: On Wednesday afternoon, Representative Mike Conaway, Republican of Texas, announced that he would not run for re-election next year. At a news conference in Midland, Mr. Conaway expressed distress at the partisan dysfunction in Congress, nodded to the term limits that his party places on committee leadership positions and said hed been pondering retirement for a year or so. He said he wanted to leave on his own terms.

title: Some Democrats Want to Decriminalize Illegal Border Crossings. Would It Work?
description: Crossing the border without permission is a crime, but the law prohibiting it has often gone unenforced since it was passed in 1929. Instead, most first-time violators are deported under civil, not criminal, proceedings.
